topic_name: Food: Where Does It Come From

canonical_explanation.text: Food is essential for all living organisms. We get our food from plants and animals. Plants provide us with fruits, vegetables, cereals, pulses, and spices. Different parts of a plant such as roots (carrot, radish), stems (potato, ginger), leaves (spinach, cabbage), flowers (cauliflower, broccoli), fruits (mango, apple), and seeds (wheat, rice, mustard) are used as food. Animals provide us with milk, eggs, meat, honey, and other products. Based on their eating habits, animals are classified as herbivores (plant eaters like cow, deer), carnivores (meat eaters like lion, tiger), and omnivores (eating both plants and animals like bear, crow, human).
rules: Plants and animals are the two main sources of food.
Different parts of plants are edible: roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruits, and seeds.
Animals provide products like milk, eggs, meat, and honey.
Herbivores eat only plants (e.g., cow, rabbit, deer).
Carnivores eat only other animals (e.g., lion, tiger, hawk).
Omnivores eat both plants and animals (e.g., bear, crow, human beings).
Ingredients are the materials needed to prepare a food item.
Most food items are prepared using ingredients from both plant and animal sources.

questions.question_text: What are the two main sources of food for human beings?
questions.explanation_correct: Plants and animals are the two main sources of food for human beings. Plants give us fruits, vegetables, cereals, and pulses, while animals give us milk, eggs, meat, and honey.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water, air, sunlight, soil, rocks, and minerals are not sources of food for humans. Our food comes from plants (fruits, vegetables, grains) and animals (milk, eggs, meat).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an ingredient obtained from plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Rice is obtained from the rice plant and is therefore a plant-based ingredient. It is one of the most commonly consumed cereals in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk comes from animals like cows and buffaloes, eggs come from hens and ducks, and honey is made by bees. Only rice among these options is a plant-based ingredient.

questions.question_text: What do we call the materials needed to prepare a food item?
questions.explanation_correct: Ingredients are the materials or items needed to prepare a food item. For example, to make dal, we need pulses, water, salt, oil, and spices as ingredients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nutrients are the useful components present in food (like carbohydrates, proteins). Minerals and vitamins are specific types of nutrients. The term for materials needed to prepare food is 'ingredients'.

questions.question_text: All the food we eat comes only from plants.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. We get food from both plants and animals. Plants give us fruits, vegetables, and cereals, while animals give us milk, eggs, meat, and honey.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because food comes from both plants and animals, not only from plants. Milk, eggs, meat, fish, and honey are all animal-based food products.

questions.question_text: Which of the following food items comes from an animal source?
questions.explanation_correct: Paneer (cottage cheese) is made from milk, which is an animal product obtained from cows or buffaloes. Therefore, paneer comes from an animal source.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat is a cereal from plants, spinach is a leafy vegetable from plants, and apple is a fruit from plants. Only paneer, which is made from animal milk, comes from an animal source.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant do we eat when we eat a carrot?
questions.explanation_correct: Carrot is a root vegetable. The orange part of the carrot that we eat is the modified tap root of the carrot plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carrot is not a stem, leaf, or flower. It is the root of the carrot plant that grows underground and stores food. Other examples of edible roots include radish, turnip, and beetroot.

questions.question_text: Spinach is an example of a food item where we eat the _______ of the plant.
questions.explanation_correct: When we eat spinach, we eat the leaves of the spinach plant. Other examples of leafy vegetables include cabbage, lettuce, and methi (fenugreek).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spinach is a leafy vegetable, so we eat its leaves, not the root, stem, or seeds. Leaves are one of the important edible parts of many plants.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a food item obtained from the seed of a plant?
questions.explanation_correct: Wheat is a seed (grain) of the wheat plant. We use wheat seeds to make flour (atta) for chapatis and bread. Rice, maize, and mustard are also examples of edible seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potato is a modified stem (tuber), cauliflower is a flower, and onion is a modified stem (bulb). Wheat is the seed of the wheat plant, making it the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Radha's mother made a dish using potato, cauliflower, and mustard oil. Which plant parts were used in this dish?
questions.explanation_correct: Potato is a modified stem (tuber), cauliflower is a flower, and mustard oil comes from mustard seeds. So the dish used stem, flower, and seed parts of plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potato is not a root — it is a modified stem (tuber) that grows underground. Cauliflower is a flower, and mustard oil is extracted from mustard seeds. The correct combination is stem, flower, and seed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs correctly matches food items with the plant part eaten?
questions.explanation_correct: Broccoli is a flower that we eat (like cauliflower), and ginger is a modified stem (rhizome) that grows underground. This is the correctly matched pair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carrot is a root (not a stem), spinach is a leaf (not a root), onion is a modified stem/bulb (not a root), radish is a root (not a stem), and cabbage is a leaf (not a seed). The correct pairing is broccoli as a flower and ginger as a stem.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an edible flower?
questions.explanation_correct: Cauliflower is the flower of the cauliflower plant that we eat. Broccoli is another example of an edible flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potato is a modified stem, carrot is a root, and ginger is a modified stem (rhizome). Cauliflower is the edible flower among these options.

questions.question_text: A student listed the following plant parts and food items: (i) Root — Radish (ii) Stem — Potato (iii) Leaf — Onion (iv) Seed — Rice. Which listing is INCORRECT?
questions.explanation_correct: Onion is NOT a leaf — it is a modified stem (bulb). The fleshy layers of an onion are modified leaves attached to a shortened stem, but the food-storing part is classified as a modified stem. The other pairings are correct: radish is a root, potato is a stem, and rice is a seed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radish is correctly classified as a root, potato as a stem (tuber), and rice as a seed. The incorrect listing is onion as a leaf — onion is actually a modified stem (bulb).

questions.question_text: Which animal product is obtained from bees?
questions.explanation_correct: Honey is produced by honeybees. Bees collect nectar from flowers and convert it into honey, which they store in their beehives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk comes from cows, buffaloes, and goats. Eggs come from hens, ducks, and other birds. Meat comes from various animals. Only honey is obtained from bees.

questions.question_text: From which of the following animals do we NOT commonly get milk?
questions.explanation_correct: We do not get milk from hens. Hens are birds and they give us eggs, not milk. Milk is obtained from mammals like cows, buffaloes, and goats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cows, buffaloes, and goats are all mammals that produce milk. Hens are birds and do not produce milk — they lay eggs instead.

questions.question_text: Ravi had a breakfast of bread, butter, and an omelette. Which of these items has ONLY animal-sourced ingredients?
questions.explanation_correct: Both butter (made from milk/cream, an animal product) and omelette (made from eggs, an animal product) are sourced from animals. Bread is made from wheat flour, which comes from plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bread is made from wheat flour (a plant product). Butter is made from milk (animal product) and omelette is made from eggs (animal product). So both butter and omelette have animal-sourced ingredients.

questions.question_text: Eggs are an animal product obtained from hens.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Eggs are indeed an animal product and hens are one of the most common sources of eggs that we eat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Hens lay eggs, which are one of the most widely consumed animal products worldwide.

questions.question_text: Which of the following food items involves both plant and animal sources?

options.text: A bowl of vegetable kheer (rice pudding with milk)

questions.explanation_correct: Vegetable kheer involves both plant sources (rice, sugar) and animal sources (milk). This makes it a food item with ingredients from both sources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plain milk comes only from animals, boiled rice comes only from plants, and fruit salad comes only from plants. Only kheer uses both rice (plant) and milk (animal), combining both sources.

questions.question_text: Animals that eat only plants are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Herbivores are animals that eat only plants or plant products. Examples include cow, buffalo, deer, rabbit, horse, and elephant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carnivores eat only other animals, omnivores eat both plants and animals, and decomposers break down dead matter. Animals that eat only plants are specifically called herbivores.

questions.question_text: A lion is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: A lion is a carnivore because it eats only the flesh of other animals. Lions hunt animals like deer, zebra, and buffalo for food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A lion does not eat plants (so it is not a herbivore), does not eat both plants and animals (so it is not an omnivore), and does not produce its own food (so it is not a producer). A lion eats only meat, making it a carnivore.

questions.question_text: Which of the following animals is an omnivore?
questions.explanation_correct: A bear is an omnivore because it eats both plants (fruits, berries, roots) and animals (fish, insects, small mammals). Other examples of omnivores include crows, dogs, and human beings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cow and deer are herbivores (they eat only plants). Tiger is a carnivore (it eats only meat). The bear is an omnivore because it eats both plants and animals.

questions.question_text: Human beings are omnivores because they eat both plant-based and animal-based food.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Human beings eat food from both plant sources (rice, vegetables, fruits) and animal sources (milk, eggs, meat), making them omnivores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Since humans eat both plant and animal foods, they are classified as omnivores.

questions.question_text: A student observed an animal eating grass in a field. Later, the same animal was seen eating insects. This animal is most likely a/an:
questions.explanation_correct: Since the animal eats both grass (plant) and insects (animals), it is an omnivore. Omnivores are animals that feed on both plants and animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A herbivore would eat only plants, and a carnivore would eat only animals. Since this animal eats both grass (plant) and insects (animals), it is classified as an omnivore.

questions.question_text: Meena is making a vegetable pulao. She uses rice, peas, carrots, beans, and ghee. How many of these ingredients come from plant sources?
questions.explanation_correct: Rice (seed), peas (seed), carrots (root), and beans (seed/fruit) are all from plant sources — that makes 4 plant-source ingredients. Ghee is made from milk, which is an animal product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ghee is an animal product (made from milk), not a plant product. The four plant-source ingredients are rice, peas, carrots, and beans.

questions.question_text: Which of the following groups contains ONLY items where we eat the root of the plant?
questions.explanation_correct: Carrot, radish, and beetroot are all roots. Potato is a modified stem (tuber), onion is a modified stem (bulb), ginger is a modified stem (rhizome), and garlic is a modified stem (bulb).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In options B, C, and D, some items are not roots: potato and onion are modified stems, ginger is a modified stem (rhizome), and garlic is a modified stem (bulb). Only option A has all roots.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct match?
questions.explanation_correct: A crow is an omnivore because it eats both plant materials (grains, fruits) and animal materials (insects, worms, small animals). Eagles are carnivores, rabbits are herbivores, and tigers are carnivores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eagle eats other animals, so it is a carnivore (not herbivore). Rabbit eats only plants, so it is a herbivore (not carnivore). Tiger eats only meat, so it is a carnivore (not omnivore). Crow eats both plants and animals, making it an omnivore.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is CORRECT about food sources?

options.text: All food items are obtained from plants only
Some food items have ingredients from both plant and animal sources
Animals cannot provide any food for humans
Seeds of all plants can be eaten as food

questions.explanation_correct: Many food items use ingredients from both sources. For example, a cake uses flour (plant), sugar (plant), milk (animal), and eggs (animal). Not all food comes from plants alone, and not all plant seeds are edible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because food also comes from animals. Option C is wrong because animals provide milk, eggs, meat, and honey. Option D is wrong because seeds of many plants are not edible or may even be poisonous.

questions.question_text: Consider the following food items: (i) Potato (ii) Carrot (iii) Ginger (iv) Radish. Which of these are obtained from the stem of a plant?
questions.explanation_correct: Potato is a modified stem (tuber) and ginger is a modified stem (rhizome). Both grow underground but are stems, not roots. Carrot and radish are true roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carrot and radish are roots, not stems. Potato (tuber) and ginger (rhizome) are both modified stems that grow underground. Many students confuse underground stems with roots.

questions.question_text: Assertion: Honey is considered an animal product. Reason: Honey is produced by honeybees from the nectar of flowers.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct but reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — honey is classified as an animal product. The reason is also correct — bees collect nectar from flowers and process it into honey. The reason correctly explains why honey is an animal product: because it is produced (processed) by an animal (bees).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both the assertion and reason are factually correct. Honey is an animal product because it is made by honeybees, and the reason explains this relationship correctly.

questions.question_text:
Read the following descriptions and identify the correct classification:
(P) An animal that eats fruits, nuts, and fish.
(Q) An animal that eats only grass and leaves.
(R) An animal that hunts and eats only other animals.
questions.explanation_correct: P eats both plant food (fruits, nuts) and animal food (fish), so it is an omnivore. Q eats only plants (grass, leaves), so it is a herbivore. R eats only animals, so it is a carnivore.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key is to look at what each animal eats. P eats both plants and animals = omnivore. Q eats only plants = herbivore. R eats only animals = carnivore. Only option B matches all three correctly.

questions.question_text: Which of the following food items has ingredients from ONLY plant sources?
questions.explanation_correct: Vegetable salad with lemon juice uses only plant ingredients — vegetables and lemon are both from plants. Curd comes from milk (animal), ghee comes from milk (animal), and butter comes from milk (animal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Curd is made from milk (animal product), ghee is made from butter/cream (animal product), and butter is made from milk (animal product). Only the vegetable salad with lemon juice is entirely plant-based.

questions.question_text: We eat the _______ of a mustard plant when we use mustard oil.
questions.explanation_correct: Mustard oil is extracted from the seeds of the mustard plant. Mustard seeds are small round seeds that contain oil, which is pressed out for cooking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mustard oil is not extracted from roots, leaves, or flowers of the mustard plant. It is the seeds of the mustard plant that are rich in oil and are pressed to produce mustard oil.

questions.question_text: Sugarcane gives us sugar. Which part of the sugarcane plant do we use to extract sugar?
questions.explanation_correct: Sugar is obtained from the stem of the sugarcane plant. The sugarcane stem stores sweet juice (sap) from which sugar is extracted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sugar is not obtained from the root, leaf, or seed of sugarcane. The thick, juicy stem of sugarcane stores the sweet sap which is processed to make sugar.

questions.question_text: Which of the following food items is NOT obtained from animals?
questions.explanation_correct: Jaggery (gur) is made from sugarcane juice or palm sap, both of which come from plants. Silk is an animal product (from silkworms, though not a food), cheese and curd are made from milk (animal product).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cheese is made from milk (animal product), curd is made from milk (animal product), and silk comes from silkworms (animal product). Jaggery is the only plant product here, made from sugarcane or palm.

questions.question_text: Which of the following animals is a herbivore?
questions.explanation_correct: A horse is a herbivore because it eats only plant-based food such as grass, hay, and grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fox is an omnivore/carnivore, crow is an omnivore, and dog is an omnivore. Horse is the only herbivore in this list, as it feeds only on grass, hay, and grains.

questions.question_text:
A student made the following table:
| Animal | Category |
| Goat | Herbivore |
| Hawk | Carnivore |
| Parrot | Omnivore |
| Bear | Omnivore |
Which row contains an error?
questions.explanation_correct: Parrot is a herbivore, not an omnivore. Parrots eat seeds, fruits, nuts, and other plant materials. They do not eat other animals. The other classifications are correct: goat is a herbivore, hawk is a carnivore, and bear is an omnivore.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Goat eats only plants (herbivore — correct), hawk eats other animals (carnivore — correct), and bear eats both plants and animals (omnivore — correct). Parrot eats only plant foods like seeds and fruits, so it should be classified as a herbivore, not an omnivore.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a reason why we need food?

options.text: Food provides energy for daily activities
Food helps in growth and repair of the body
Food makes us taller than other people

questions.explanation_correct: Food does not specifically make us taller than other people. Height depends on genetics and overall nutrition. Food provides energy, helps in growth and repair, and contains nutrients that protect us from diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food provides energy (correct), helps in growth and repair (correct), and protects from diseases through nutrients like vitamins and minerals (correct). However, food does not guarantee being taller than others — height depends on many factors including genetics.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following correctly lists food items grouped by the plant part we eat?
Group X: Carrot, Beetroot, Turnip
Group Y: Potato, Ginger, Turmeric

options.text: Group X — Stems, Group Y — Roots
Group X — Roots, Group Y — Stems
Group X — Roots, Group Y — Leaves
Group X — Stems, Group Y — Seeds

questions.explanation_correct: Group X (carrot, beetroot, turnip) are all roots. Group Y (potato, ginger, turmeric) are all modified stems — potato is a tuber, ginger is a rhizome, and turmeric is a rhizome.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carrot, beetroot, and turnip are roots that grow underground to store food. Potato (tuber), ginger (rhizome), and turmeric (rhizome) are all modified stems, even though they grow underground.

questions.question_text: Which statement about animal food products is INCORRECT?

options.text: Milk is obtained from cows, buffaloes, and goats
Eggs are laid by hens, ducks, and quails
Honey is directly collected from flowers by humans
Meat includes the flesh of chicken, goat, and fish

questions.explanation_correct: Honey is NOT directly collected from flowers by humans. Honeybees collect nectar from flowers, process it, and store it as honey in their hives. Humans then collect the honey from beehives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk is indeed obtained from cows, buffaloes, and goats (correct). Eggs are laid by hens, ducks, and quails (correct). Meat includes flesh of chicken, goat, and fish (correct). But honey is made by bees from nectar — humans do not collect it directly from flowers.

questions.question_text: The teeth of a herbivore differ from those of a carnivore because herbivores need to:

options.text: Tear flesh, so they have sharp pointed teeth
Grind plant material, so they have broad, flat teeth
Swallow food whole, so they have no teeth
Eat both plants and animals, so they have mixed teeth

questions.explanation_correct: Herbivores have broad, flat grinding teeth (molars) because they need to chew and grind tough plant material like grass and leaves. Carnivores have sharp, pointed teeth for tearing flesh.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sharp pointed teeth are found in carnivores for tearing flesh. Herbivores have flat teeth for grinding plants. Option C is incorrect as most herbivores do have teeth. Option D describes omnivores, not herbivores.

questions.question_text: During a school picnic, the students had the following items: idli, coconut chutney, boiled eggs, and orange juice. How many of these items come from plant sources only?
questions.explanation_correct: Idli (made from rice and urad dal — both plants), coconut chutney (made from coconut — a plant), and orange juice (from oranges — a plant) are all from plant sources only. Boiled eggs are from animals. So 3 items come from plant sources only.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiled eggs come from hens (an animal source). The other three items — idli (rice and dal), coconut chutney (coconut), and orange juice (oranges) — all come from plant sources only.

questions.question_text: We eat the fruit of which of the following plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Mango is a fruit that we eat. Fruits develop from the flower of a plant and usually contain seeds. Other examples of edible fruits include apple, banana, and orange.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potato is a stem (tuber), wheat provides seeds (grains), and spinach provides leaves. Mango is the fruit among these options.

questions.question_text: In the coriander (dhania) plant, we can eat both the leaves and the seeds. This shows that:

options.text: Only one part of a plant can be used as food
More than one part of the same plant can be used as food
All parts of every plant are edible
Seeds and leaves are the same plant part

questions.explanation_correct: The coriander plant shows that more than one part of the same plant can be eaten — we use its leaves (for garnishing and chutney) and its seeds (as a spice). Similarly, in mustard plant, we eat both leaves and seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not true that only one part can be used (option A). Not all parts of every plant are edible (option C) — some parts may be poisonous. Seeds and leaves are different plant parts (option D). The correct answer is that multiple parts of the same plant can be edible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an animal product used as food?
questions.explanation_correct: Cooking oil is obtained from plant sources like mustard seeds, sunflower seeds, groundnuts, coconut, or soybean. It is a plant product, not an animal product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honey (from bees), milk (from cows/buffaloes), and eggs (from hens) are all animal products. Cooking oil is extracted from plant seeds and is the only plant product in this list.

questions.question_text: Which of the following sets contains ONLY carnivores?
questions.explanation_correct: Tiger, eagle, and shark are all carnivores — they eat only other animals. Tigers hunt deer and other mammals, eagles hunt fish and small animals, and sharks eat fish and marine animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In option A, bear is an omnivore. In option C, crow is an omnivore and fox can be an omnivore. In option D, sparrow is mainly a herbivore/omnivore. Only option B has all carnivores.

questions.question_text: A teacher asked her students to name food items and their sources. Which student gave the INCORRECT answer?

options.text: Aman said: 'Paneer comes from milk, which is an animal product'
Rohit said: 'Rice comes from the seeds of the rice plant'
Sara said: 'Honey is an animal product made by bees'

questions.explanation_correct: Priya's answer is incorrect. Mushrooms are NOT plants — they are fungi. Fungi are a separate group of organisms that do not make their own food. They grow on decaying organic matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paneer is indeed made from milk, an animal product (Aman is correct). Rice is from seeds of the rice plant (Rohit is correct). Honey is indeed made by bees (Sara is correct). Mushrooms are fungi, not plants, so Priya's answer is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Which plant allows us to use the maximum number of different parts as food?

options.text: Mustard plant (seeds, leaves, oil from seeds)

questions.explanation_correct: The banana plant provides the maximum number of different parts as food — we eat the fruit (banana), the flower (banana flower/blossom used in cooking), and the stem (tender stem used in South Indian cuisine). That is 3 different plant parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mustard plant gives us seeds and leaves (2 parts — oil comes from the same seeds). The rice plant gives mainly seeds, and the carrot plant gives mainly roots. The banana plant provides 3 distinct edible parts: fruit, flower, and stem.

questions.question_text: A student claims: 'Since bees collect nectar from flowers, honey should be classified as a plant product, not an animal product.' What is the best response?

options.text: The student is correct — honey is a plant product
Honey is classified as an animal product because bees process and transform the nectar into honey
Honey is neither a plant nor an animal product

questions.explanation_correct: Although nectar comes from flowers (plants), the bees collect it, process it with enzymes in their bodies, and transform it into honey. Since an animal (the bee) produces it through biological processing, honey is classified as an animal product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honey is not simply collected nectar — bees chemically transform the nectar using enzymes. This biological processing by an animal makes it an animal product, not a plant product. It is certainly not a mineral product.

questions.question_text: An animal has sharp, curved claws, forward-facing eyes, and pointed canine teeth. Based on these features, this animal is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: Sharp curved claws (for catching prey), forward-facing eyes (for depth perception during hunting), and pointed canine teeth (for tearing flesh) are all adaptations of carnivores. These features help them hunt and eat other animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbivores have flat grinding teeth and side-facing eyes. The features described — sharp claws, forward-facing eyes, and pointed canines — are classic carnivore adaptations for hunting and eating prey.

questions.question_text: Which of the following food items requires ingredients from both plant and animal sources?

options.text: Scrambled eggs with onion and tomato

questions.explanation_correct: Scrambled eggs with onion and tomato requires eggs (animal source), onion (plant source), and tomato (plant source). This uses ingredients from both plant and animal sources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fruit salad and boiled vegetables use only plant ingredients. Plain lassi uses only curd/yogurt (animal source). Only scrambled eggs with onion and tomato combines both plant (onion, tomato) and animal (eggs) ingredients.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly explains why a deer is classified as a herbivore?

options.text: Because it lives in the forest
Because it feeds only on grass, leaves, and other plant materials
Because it has four legs and a tail

questions.explanation_correct: A deer is classified as a herbivore because of its diet — it feeds only on grass, leaves, fruits, and other plant materials. The classification is based on what the animal eats, not where it lives or how it looks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Living in a forest, running fast, or having four legs are not reasons for being a herbivore. The classification of animals as herbivore, carnivore, or omnivore is based solely on their diet — what they eat.
